awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Dermatologist-level detection of suspicious pigmented skin lesions from high-resolution full-body images
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Program (STTR) Phase I project is to improve outcomes in dermatology and enable improved clinical care in the absence of specialists.  The proposed technology enables cost-effective screening for cancer, psoriasis, atopic dermatitis, and other inflammatory skin conditions. In the United States, psoriasis affects about 8 million people while about 31.6 million people in the United States have some form of eczema, including atopic dermatitis. The proposed system generates a highly magnified image of the skin for analysis by a clinician or an artificial-intelligence based automated system. 

This Small Business Technology Transfer Program (STTR) Phase I project integrates several subsystems: 1) a scanner and software to capture and reconstruct super high-resolution (dermatoscope level) model of the entire skin surface of patients in a matter of minutes; 2) a multispectral illumination system to provide more information than currently available from a typical white-light systems, potentially leading to superior sensitivity and specify in lesion detection and classification; and 3) a system to find and classify lesions automatically from high-resolution images.  This system advances the automated classification of images beyond those filtered previously by a clinician. Moreover, the system's UV illuminations system potentially can be used in a photodynamic treatment regimen.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

STTR Phase I:   Dermatologist-level detection of suspicious pigmented skin lesions from high-resolution full-body images

Dated: 1/22/2023

 

During the Phase I project, the team set out to develop the proof of concept for the  world’s first full body skin cancer screening system.  Some of the main outcomes of the Phase I effort include:

 

  • Classification of the lesions from wide field of view, total body photography images (as opposed to small field of view dermascopic images): The team considered many datasets and AI models.  The best AI classification model (AUC = 86.7%) was found to be a deep network based on the Xception model that also used computed ABCD (asymmetry, border, color and diameter) feature values as well as other meta data. This model outperformed the most recent published results (Hamarneh et al. Direct Model AUC = 84.2%), though it did not outperform the dermatologists best practices (iDScore method AUC = 91.7%).
  • Improvement of the Ugly Duckling  classification (i.e. classification of lesions that look different the majority of other lesions) model from Wyss Institute:  We expanded the scope of the analysis from only upper back to the entire body while adding additional capability. In our implementation the algorithm does not get confounded by body features such as nipples and nostrils.
  • The advancement of scanning capability: We introduced improved depth of field and the ability to focus on specific patient-body-shapes
  • The design and publication of  “DICOM TBP Work Item”: Designed a work item that can accommodate all current and future data-rich (including multi-spectral) Total Body Photography systems and is compatible with the DICOM standard for dermoscopy
  • A brand new Clinician’s Software application: The Clinician’s software includes the following features:  
  1. A Virtual Dermatoscope that can provide highly magnified images of the lesions
  2. A Machine learning option allowing the clinician to opt for CycleGAN style transfer technology in order to render the magnified images in dermatoscopic style (as opposed to clinical style).
  3. Best View option that automatically presents the super-resolved image crop from the point of view (selected from over 500 images captured with the scan) with the best focus on the area within Virtual dermatoscope
  4. Automatic and continuous computation and display of the  scale marks within the Virtual Dermatoscope
  5. Absolute and Ugly Duckling classifications are presented as heatmaps to attract the attention of the Dermatologist to significant lesions

In other words, at the onset of this project the LumoScanner hardware and a version of the operator’s software was already installed at our first client site.   This system was able to collect patient data but not much more.  Since the completion the Phase I effort, this system has been upgraded with improved scanning hardware, Operator’s Software (data collection software), and a brand new image processing pipeline and Clinician Software (data analysis software).  As a result, the researchers at our first installation cite can now perform highly effective computer-assisted full body skin examination through examining the scans without the patient being present.  

 


Last Modified: 01/24/2023
Modified by: Davood Tashayyod
por.por_txt_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

STTR Phase I:   Dermatologist-level detection of suspicious pigmented skin lesions from high-resolution full-body images

Dated: 1/22/2023

 

During the Phase I project, the team set out to develop the proof of concept for the  world’s first full body skin cancer screening system.  Some of the main outcomes of the Phase I effort include:

 

Classification of the lesions from wide field of view, total body photography images (as opposed to small field of view dermascopic images): The team considered many datasets and AI models.  The best AI classification model (AUC = 86.7%) was found to be a deep network based on the Xception model that also used computed ABCD (asymmetry, border, color and diameter) feature values as well as other meta data. This model outperformed the most recent published results (Hamarneh et al. Direct Model AUC = 84.2%), though it did not outperform the dermatologists best practices (iDScore method AUC = 91.7%).
Improvement of the Ugly Duckling  classification (i.e. classification of lesions that look different the majority of other lesions) model from Wyss Institute:  We expanded the scope of the analysis from only upper back to the entire body while adding additional capability. In our implementation the algorithm does not get confounded by body features such as nipples and nostrils.
The advancement of scanning capability: We introduced improved depth of field and the ability to focus on specific patient-body-shapes
The design and publication of  "DICOM TBP Work Item": Designed a work item that can accommodate all current and future data-rich (including multi-spectral) Total Body Photography systems and is compatible with the DICOM standard for dermoscopy
A brand new Clinician’s Software application: The Clinician’s software includes the following features:  


A Virtual Dermatoscope that can provide highly magnified images of the lesions
A Machine learning option allowing the clinician to opt for CycleGAN style transfer technology in order to render the magnified images in dermatoscopic style (as opposed to clinical style).
Best View option that automatically presents the super-resolved image crop from the point of view (selected from over 500 images captured with the scan) with the best focus on the area within Virtual dermatoscope
Automatic and continuous computation and display of the  scale marks within the Virtual Dermatoscope
Absolute and Ugly Duckling classifications are presented as heatmaps to attract the attention of the Dermatologist to significant lesions


In other words, at the onset of this project the LumoScanner hardware and a version of the operator’s software was already installed at our first client site.   This system was able to collect patient data but not much more.  Since the completion the Phase I effort, this system has been upgraded with improved scanning hardware, Operator’s Software (data collection software), and a brand new image processing pipeline and Clinician Software (data analysis software).  As a result, the researchers at our first installation cite can now perform highly effective computer-assisted full body skin examination through examining the scans without the patient being present.
